abstract: In the manufacturing industry, preventative maintenance of cutting tools plays a critical role in ensuring operational efficiency and minimizing downtime. This paper addresses the problem of accurately predicting the wear level of a cutting tool by applying artificial neural networks. The study uses an extensive dataset derived from real-life manufacturing scenarios and uses synthetic and experimental data for illustrative purposes. The use of depth of cut, continuous vibration monitoring using an accelerometer, spindle speed, feed rate and cutting speed contribute to a holistic approach to predicting tool wear in milling processes. This comprehensive set of features is designed to capture the nuanced interactions between machining conditions and tool degradation, thereby improving the model‚Äôs predictive accuracy. The architecture, features and algorithm for training the network are described. A neural network has been created and configured to determine tool wear during the milling process. The process of training and debugging a neural network is clearly displayed on the graphs. The performance of the network was tested using test data, which allowed us to obtain good results.

Abstract. In the manufacturing industry,  preventative maintenance of 
cutting tools plays a critical role in ensuring operational efficiency and 
minimizing downtime. This paper addresses the problem of accurately 
predicting the wear level of a cutting tool by applying artificial neural 
networks. The study uses an extens ive dataset derived from real-life 
manufacturing scenarios and uses synthetic and experi mental data for 
illustrative purposes. The use of depth of cut, continuous vibration 
monitoring using an accelerometer, spindle speed, feed rate and cutting 
speed contribute to a holistic approach to predicting tool wear in milling 
processes. This comprehensive set of features is designed to capture the 
nuanced interactions betw een machining conditions and tool degradation, 
thereby improving the model's predictive accuracy. The architecture, 
features and algorithm for training the network are described. A neural 
network has been created and configured to determine tool wear during the 
milling process. The process of training and debugging a neural network is 
clearly displayed on the graphs. The performance of the network was tested 
using test data, which allowed us to obtain good results. 
1 Introduction 
The application of artificial neural networks (ANN) represents significant progress in various 
scientific fields, including mechanical engin eering. The development and use of ANNs to 
improve the efficiency of m achining processes is gaining popularity among researchers 
around the world. The use of artificial neural networks is du e to their ability to learn based 
on creating connections between input and outp ut data. One of the main advantages is 
network performance, characterized by training time and deviation of the output signal from 
the reference. The main influence on perfor mance is the network ar chitecture and training 
method. When properly configured, such a network provides the opportunity to solve 
problems without using complex mathematical equations [1-7]. The objective of this study 
is to conduct an investigation of cutting tool wear prediction using artificial neural network 
in the process of milling operations. The process of research involves development of a model 
and its architecture, conduct normalization in order to lessen calculation times, and carry on

2 Methodology 
Steel AISI 5140 is an important material widely used in any industry, plays a key role in the 
production of various components. The influence of cutting tool wear on the processing of 
AISI 5140 is significant and affects not only the quality of the finished product, but also 
production costs. Accurate prediction of tool wear conditions becomes the most important 
aspect to ensure the desired surface quality of parts and timely replacement of cutting tools. 
There is a clear need to develop an effective tool condition monitoring (TCM) system aimed 
at increasing productivity and automating the metalworking process, especially on automated 
machines. Although numerous attempts have been made in the past to develop TCM systems 
using data from multiple sensors such as dynamometers, accelerometers, acoustic emissions, 
and electrical measurements, success has been limited by the complex nature of tool wear 
mechanisms. In contrast, alternative techniques that include parameters such as cutting speed 
and depth of cut offer promise for effective tool condition monitoring. The importance of 
predicting tool wear based on these parameters is emphasized by its impact on ensuring the 
required surface quality of parts and timely replacement of tools [7-10]. 
Observation from the literature  shows a noticeable gap in the field of tool condition 
monitoring in high-speed machining of steel AI SI 5140, especially with a primary focus on 
single-edge tools. Previous studies using SVM method for condition monitoring of CNC gear 
grinding machine further highlight the need for comprehensive research in this field [11-13]. 
This study takes a special approach of continuously monitoring tool wear on a high-speed 
machining machine using parameters such as cutting speed and depth of cut instead of 
traditional vibration signals. Using machine l earning algorithms, sp ecifically the decision 
tree algorithm, the study aims to correlate tool states. Extensive experiments were carried out 
using coated multi-hole carbide tools under different machining conditions, with special

statistical features were extracted for use in  the decision tree algorithm. Machine learning 
algorithms including artificial neural networks and decision tree algorithm were used to 
further classify the tool wear condition and their classification performance was carefully 
compared. Determining the most effective f eature classifier concludes this study, 
contributing to the ongoing debate on optimizing tool condition monitoring strategies in high-
speed machining scenarios. The graphical representation of the study and methodology is 
represented in Figure 2.

In this study, the dataset utilized for tool condition monitoring encompasses a diverse set 
of machining parameters crucial for understanding the dynamics of tool wear during high-
speed machining of AISI 5140 steel. The data is sourced from controlled experiments 
conducted on a high-speed milling machine, focusing on the machining of AISI 5140 using 
multi-hole coated carbide tools. The primary parameters included in the dataset are depth of 
cut, continuous vibration monito ring (accelerometer data), spi ndle speed, feed rate, cutting 
speed. A fragment of the sample is presented in Table 1. The full sample contains 120 rows.

The dataset undergoes preprocessing steps to ensure its suitability for analysis and model 
development. Data processing techniques are applied to extract statistical characteristics from 
the continuously monitored parameters. This step is crucial for transforming raw sensor data 
into meaningful features that capture the essence of tool wear conditions during machining. 
Additionally, the Decision Tree algorithm is empl oyed as part of the preprocessing steps to 
extract dominant features from the dataset.  This algorithm aids in identifying the most 
relevant variables that contribute significantly to the prediction of tool wear conditions. 
This curated and preprocessed dataset serv es as the foundation for the subsequent 
application of machine learning algorithms, such as artificial neural networks and decision 
tree algorithms, to predict and classify tool wear conditions during high-speed machining of 
AISI 5140 steel. The careful selection and preprocessing of the dataset are vital elements in 
ensuring the accuracy and effectiveness of the tool condition monitoring system developed 
in this study.

3 Results and discussion 
3.1 Model architecture 
The Artificial Neural Network (ANN) architectur e employed in this study is designed to 
effectively capture hierarchical  features from both vibration signals and above mentioned 
parameters of machining conditions for the prediction of cutting tool wear in high-speed 
machining of steel AISI 5140. The model begins with a series of artificial layers responsible 
for feature extraction from the input statistical dataset. Each layer is followed by a Rectified 
Linear Unit (ReLU) activation function to introduce non-linearity and enhance the network's 
ability to capture complex patterns. Additionally , max-pooling layers are incorporated as a 
normalization means and to reduce the computational complexity. 
Simultaneously, continuous vibration signals are processed through a separate branch of 
the network. These signals undergo initial preprocessing, including noise removal and 
segmentation, and are subsequently fed through artificial layers followed by ReLU activation 
functions to extract relevant temporal features. Max-pooling layers are also employed in this 
branch to down-sample the temporal dimensions. To merge the information extracted from 
both branches, a concatenation layer is introduc ed, facilitating the fusion of spatial features 
from images and temporal features from vibration signals. Following the concatenation, fully 
connected layers are utilized to combine the extracted features and generate a comprehensive 
representation of the input data for the final prediction. 
To optimize model performance and prevent overfitting, excluded layers are strategically 
inserted after fully connected layers, randomly excluding a portion of neurons during training 
to improve generalization. Batch normalization is used to stabilize and accelerate the learning 
process by normalizing the input data of each layer. The model is trained using a data set that 
includes a diverse range of processing conditions and corresponding tool wear 
measurements. The learning process involves minimizing a suitable loss function by back 
propagation of the error and adjusting the para meters of the model to improve the accuracy 
of its prediction. To evaluate the effectivene ss of the model, extensive checks and tests are 
carried out on independent data sets, evaluating its ability to generalize invisible processing 
scenarios. The results demonstrate the ability of the proposed ANN architecture to accurately 
predict the wear of the cutting tool during high-speed processing of AISI 5140 steel, 
demonstrating its potential as a valuable tool for monitoring the condition of the tool in real 
time and optimizing maintenance in industrial conditions. 
3.2 Training procedure 
Neural network consists of interconnected layers covering the input, hidden and output levels. 
Inside these layers, artificial neurons are equipped with activation functions. These neurons 
receive input data using a we ighted sum approach  when faced with multiple inputs, and 
eventually generate output data based on their activation functions. The learning process 
involves adjusting the weights by comparing the output of the network with the desired output 
data using the functions selected by the J48 algorithm, namely standard error, kurtosis and 
median. The neural network ar chitecture adopted in this study embodies a backward error 
propagation model with direct communication. In particular, it includes a model with one 
hidden layer containing 10 neurons, each of which is characterized by activation functions of 
the sigmoid colon. The training uses 70% of the available data (61 data points), and the 
remaining 30% is allocated for testing (13 data points) and cross-validation (13 data points). 
The selection of data points for these phases is carried out randomly. The output layer of the 
neural network serves as a representation of the states of the instrument, classifying them into 
"good condition", "average servi ce life" and "critical". After training, the network is tested

When extending the assessment to a set of test data, only one classification error was 
detected, which gave a classification efficiency of 92.3%. Such high performance at the 
verification stage confirms the ability of the network to generalize new and previously 
unknown data. Subsequently, when applied to a set of test data, the model demonstrated a 
classification efficiency of 92.3% with small deviations. This result highlights the reliability 
and consistency of the model in making accurate predictions for different data sets. 
Considering the combined performance of data  sets for training, validation and testing, 
the overall classification efficiency is an impressive 95.4%. This high level of accuracy and 
consistency once again confirms the effectiveness of the developed neural network model in 
the effective recognition and classification of tool states. 
Moreover, the reliability of the neural network model is further emphasized by its ability 
to maintain high classification efficiency in va rious data sets, which reflects its adaptability 
to changes in processing conditions. The excellent characteristics of the model not only 
confirm its reliability for predicting tool wear  during high-speed processing of AISI 5140 
steel, but also suggest its potential applicability to similar production processes with different 
materials and parameters. As industries continue to explore the benefits of advanced 
preventive maintenance strategies, the demonstr ated success of this neural network model 
promises to increase efficiency, reduce downtime, and ultimately optimize tool life across a 
wide range of processing operations.

4 Conclusion 
In this investigation, an experimental setup was configured to monitor cutting tool conditions 
within a high-speed machining center, using parameters such as depth of cute, federate, 
spindle speed, cutting speed and continuous vibration. Decision tree algorithms, specifically 
J48, were employed for feature reduction, while both J48 and ANN algorithms were applied 
6

TITDS-XIV-2023
for tool condition classification. Key statistical features such as standard error, median, and 
kurtosis emerged as pivotal factors in accura tely classifying the cutting tool's condition. 
Comparative performance an alysis between the J48 al gorithm and Feed-Forward 
Backpropagation Neural Network revealed notab le results. The classification efficiency of 
the J48 algorithm and ANN stood at 94.3% and 95.4%, respectively, demonstrating high 
accuracy in predicting tool co nditions. Notably, the ANN outperformed the J48 algorithm, 
misclassifying only four input data points out of the total 87.
